results.title: Days of reckoning
results.creator_credit: Millbank Films, Lloyds Bank and Ron Tanner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Starting your own business”.
The third and final part of the series, Starting Your Own Business which traces the fortunes of three people starting their own businesses. Examines the only surviving member of the trio, an engineer whose business is in its third year. He is presented with the opportunity to expand and must reach a quick decision. Focuses on forward planning and monitoring performance.

results.title: Days of Heaven
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Siobhan Bowers, Harold Schneider and Terrence Malick
results.brief_description: This visually sumptuous film is the story of three young slum dwellers who are forced to leave Chicago and search for work in the wheat fields of Texas. It is the turn-of-the-century and the depression has created enormous poverty. Bill (Richard Gere) forms a plan to inherit the fortune of his employer, and secure a future for his girlfriend (Brooke Adams) and sister (Linda Manz). This sets in train a chain of deceit and betrayal which leads to tragedy. The cinematography of the stark Texas landscape is by Academy Award winning Nestor Alemandros. The film also stars writer Sam Shepard. Critically “Days of Heaven” has been acclaimed as a leading film of the 1970’s Hollywood “new wave”.

results.title: Days of Echuca
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Barbara Day
results.brief_description: Barbara courageously and openly speaks of the hardships she has endured in her life and how she has managed to recover from the tragedies of her life because she draws support from her spirituality, her family and her community. This story was produced as part of a project called Voices from the Riverlands, in partnership with the Njernda Aboriginal Corporation.

results.title: Days of destruction
results.brief_description: Examines and chronicles the January, 1973 eruption of the volcano Eldfell on the Icelandic island of Aeimaey. Shows how scientists studied the eruption and documents the civil defence personnel and towns people as they attempted to save buildings from approaching lava flow. Depicts the evacuation of the 5,000 inhabitants, both by air and sea. Graphically captures scenes of bellowing craters, flowing lava and burning and collapsing buildings.

results.title: Days of clear water
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Emma Case and ACMI
results.brief_description: Emma describes her life growing up with her nan, an independent lady who loved to tend to her garden and go for walks along the river. When her nan passed away, Emma lost not only her nan but her best friend.

results.title: Days of being wild
results.creator_credit: Rover Tang, In-gear Film and Wong
results.brief_description: Wong Kar-Wai has become one of the most respected and influential filmmakers in the world since coming to prominence in the 1990s. He is a highly imaginative film stylist, whose sensuous mise-en-scene, radical editing and fragmented narratives seem aptly appropriate for an increasingly decentered postmodern world. This early film, “Days of Being Wild”, is set in 1960 and examines the relationships Yuddi (Leslie Cheung), has with three women; his courtesan adopted mother, and his two very different girlfriends (Maggie Cheung and Carina Lau). Spoilt, pampered, rich and decadent, Yuddi seems to have everything he could ask for in life, but his one real desire remains unfulfilled; to discover the identity of his natural mother. Set in a searing hot Hong Kong summer, “Days of Being Wild” is a highly erotic and cynical examination of a young bourgeois man, devoid of self-discipline, who is able to remain a “boy” through his exploitation of adoring women. In this early film, the plush warm lighting, the rich cinematography and the exuberant, playful editing already reveal the spectacular craft and the romantic sensibility that distinguishes all of Kar-Wai’s films. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Days I'll remember in South Australia
results.creator_credit: Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation and Howard Rubie
results.brief_description: The star quality of the state of South Australia and one of its daughters, Julie Anthony, is revealed in this prestigious tourist film. Specially conceived music, and superb visuals combine to present the major tourist attractions of South Australia. The River Murray, Port Lincoln, the Barossa Valley, the Adelaide Hills, the Flinders Ranges, and the city of Adelaide are featured. Julie Anthony’s singing adds a special dimension to the whole film

results.title: Daydreams (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Drawings by Anne Graham, and words by Peter Homewood, portray the thoughts of an old lady looking back on her life, recalling faces, places and associated events. One face eludes her faded memory, it is her own face in her youth.
results.description: Drawings by Anne Graham, and words by Peter Homewood, portray the thoughts of an old lady looking back on her life, recalling faces, places and associated events. One face eludes her faded memory, it is her own face in her youth.

results.title: Daybreak in Udi
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: The Abaja Ibos, with the advice of the District Officer, in the Udi division of Nigeria, build a maternity home and show how ancient prejudices are overcome in the development of their territory.

results.title: Daybreak Express
results.brief_description: A short film that captures the mood of traversing New York City from day to night. Scored to a Duke Ellington track, entitled Daybreak Express, the film recalls a vibrant youthful city at the height of its mid-century pre-eminence. Pure Jazz
